poem:
**Folklore Fables in the Flat Cap Era**

Clarkson's cap, a crown of common lands,  
nostrils deep in troughs of village tales.  
Hurley whispers barrow-born secrets,  
Lee's quip-carved grins at library hearths.  
In pages, the past unfurls its roots,  
each leaf a warning in woodsmoke ink.  
Folk shadows dance in candlelit corners,  
haunting minds with rural dreams.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Flat-cap Clarkson only wants his nose in the trough | Stewart Lee I read Andrew Michael Hurley’s new novel, Barrowbeck, in preparation for co-hosting Tales of the Weird, a timely event on the folk horror genre at the British Library earlier this month. I’m not the most informed commentator on this literary subset by any means, but I am, after Mark Gatiss, one of the most famous, and so I am often asked to pontificate". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
